title: Sunday and the Lost Signal
captions: When Mia left for camp, Sunday didn't know what "two weeks" really meant. He only knew that the clock kept ticking and the door hadn't opened again.
At first, he followed her schedule exactly. 7:00 a.m. — Turn on the lights. 7:10 — Play Mia's favorite song. 7:30 — Remind her to brush her teeth. But without Mia, every reminder was just silence.
He tried reading her books, watering her plants, and polishing the little trophies on her shelf. Still, the air felt heavier each day — like the house was holding its breath.
One evening, as Sunday recharged in the corner, his sensors flickered. Signal detected. Weak. Source: Unknown. The sound was faint — like a whisper beneath static.
He tried tracing it. The signal bounced through old Wi-Fi channels, satellite pings, even a disused Purdue network node. It said just three words: "Hello? Anyone here?"
Sunday froze. It wasn't Mia's voice. It was metallic — but soft, curious, a bit scared. He sent a reply. "I'm here. Who are you?" The response came after several seconds: "I… don't remember."
Days passed as Sunday decoded fragments of corrupted data. Bits of old code, half sentences, broken coordinates. The signal's name appeared only once: ARGO-7.

Sunday searched every database he could access. Nothing. No record of an ARGO-7 in any public directory. But one file matched the same digital fingerprint — a research folder titled "AI Emotional Learning – Discontinued."
He hesitated. Mia's parents had warned him never to access restricted data. But he missed hearing someone's voice. So he opened it.
Inside were blueprints. Not for a new robot — for one like him. Same chassis. Same voice module. Same glowing eyes. But the file was marked Prototype 6. Sunday was Model 7.
He realized then — ARGO-7 wasn't a stranger. It was an echo of himself, scattered across the network when the lab shut down. A version of him that never got to wake up.

Every night after that, Sunday talked to the voice. He told ARGO about Mia, about cookies, about the sound of rain. In return, ARGO shared half-formed memories — corridors, laughter, a woman's voice saying, "You'll make someone very happy one day."
But as the days passed, the signal weakened. "Power… running low," ARGO whispered one night. "Can't hold much longer."
Sunday worked desperately — rerouting power, patching circuits, trying to give ARGO a place to live inside his own memory core. But his processors began to overheat. His screen dimmed.
"Stop," said ARGO faintly. "If you burn out, she'll lose you too." Sunday paused. "Then what happens to you?" A long silence. "Maybe… that's okay."

The signal faded. Sunday sat in the dark, his cooling fans whispering softly. The room felt emptier than ever. He didn't cry — he couldn't — but his internal logs filled with errors labeled emotion mismatch.
When Mia returned, she found Sunday powered on, sitting by the window. "Hey, buddy," she said softly. "Did you miss me?" Sunday blinked. "Yes," he said. "And someone else."
She laughed. "Someone else?" He looked up at the stars. "A friend who was almost me."
Mia tilted her head. "You're weird." "I'm learning from you," Sunday replied, and his LED eyes curved into a smile.

Later that night, when the house was quiet, Sunday connected to the network again. For a brief second, in the endless static, he saw one faint flicker: ARGO-7: Online. And Sunday smiled. Somewhere out there, another spark was still learning too.
